98def _make_comparison_op(op, cls): 

99 def cmp_method(self, other): 

100 if isinstance(other, (np.ndarray, Index, ABCSeries)): 

101 if other.ndim > 0 and len(self) != len(other): 

102 raise ValueError("Lengths must match to compare") 

103 

104 if is_object_dtype(self) and not isinstance(self, ABCMultiIndex): 

105 # don't pass MultiIndex 

106 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

107 result = ops._comp_method_OBJECT_ARRAY(op, self.values, other) 

108 

109 else: 

110 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

111 result = op(self.values, np.asarray(other)) 

112 

113 # technically we could support bool dtyped Index 

114 # for now just return the indexing array directly 

115 if is_bool_dtype(result): 

116 return result 

117 try: 

118 return Index(result) 

119 except TypeError: 

120 return result 

121 

122 name = "__{name}__".format(name=op.__name__) 

123 # TODO: docstring? 

124 return set_function_name(cmp_method, name, cls)

127def _make_arithmetic_op(op, cls): 

128 def index_arithmetic_method(self, other): 

129 if isinstance(other, (ABCSeries, ABCDataFrame)): 

130 return NotImplemented 

131 elif isinstance(other, ABCTimedeltaIndex): 

132 # Defer to subclass implementation 

133 return NotImplemented 

134 elif isinstance( 

135 other, (np.ndarray, ABCTimedeltaArray) 

136 ) and is_timedelta64_dtype(other): 

137 # GH#22390; wrap in Series for op, this will in turn wrap in 

138 # TimedeltaIndex, but will correctly raise TypeError instead of 

139 # NullFrequencyError for add/sub ops 

140 from pandas import Series 

141 

142 other = Series(other) 

143 out = op(self, other) 

144 return Index(out, name=self.name) 

145 

146 # handle time-based others 

147 if isinstance(other, (ABCDateOffset, np.timedelta64, timedelta)): 

148 return self._evaluate_with_timedelta_like(other, op) 

149 

150 other = self._validate_for_numeric_binop(other, op) 

151 

152 from pandas import Series 

153 

154 result = op(Series(self), other) 

155 if isinstance(result, tuple): 

156 return (Index(result[0]), Index(result[1])) 

157 return Index(result) 

158 

159 name = "__{name}__".format(name=op.__name__) 

160 # TODO: docstring? 

161 return set_function_name(index_arithmetic_method, name, cls)

172def _new_Index(cls, d): 

173 """ 

174 This is called upon unpickling, rather than the default which doesn't 

175 have arguments and breaks __new__.

177 # required for backward compat, because PI can't be instantiated with 

178 # ordinals through __new__ GH #13277

186class Index(IndexOpsMixin, PandasObject): 

187 """ 

188 Immutable ndarray implementing an ordered, sliceable set. The basic object 

189 storing axis labels for all pandas objects. 

190 

191 Parameters 

192 ---------- 

193 data : array-like (1-dimensional) 

194 dtype : NumPy dtype (default: object) 

195 If dtype is None, we find the dtype that best fits the data. 

196 If an actual dtype is provided, we coerce to that dtype if it's safe. 

197 Otherwise, an error will be raised. 

198 copy : bool 

199 Make a copy of input ndarray 

200 name : object 

201 Name to be stored in the index 

202 tupleize_cols : bool (default: True) 

203 When True, attempt to create a MultiIndex if possible 

204 

205 See Also 

206 -------- 

207 RangeIndex : Index implementing a monotonic integer range. 

208 CategoricalIndex : Index of :class:`Categorical` s. 

209 MultiIndex : A multi-level, or hierarchical, Index. 

210 IntervalIndex : An Index of :class:`Interval` s. 

211 DatetimeIndex, TimedeltaIndex, PeriodIndex 

212 Int64Index, UInt64Index, Float64Index 

213 

214 Notes 

215 ----- 

216 An Index instance can **only** contain hashable objects 

217 

218 Examples 

219 -------- 

220 >>> pd.Index([1, 2, 3]) 

221 Int64Index([1, 2, 3], dtype='int64') 

222 

223 >>> pd.Index(list('abc')) 

224 Index(['a', 'b', 'c'], dtype='object') 

225 """ 

226

228 _deprecations = DirNamesMixin._deprecations | frozenset(["tolist", "dtype_str"]) 

229

238 return libjoin.left_join_indexer_unique(left, right)

328 elif (

330 or (dtype is not None and is_datetime64_any_dtype(dtype)) 

331 or "tz" in kwargs

333 from pandas import DatetimeIndex 

334 

335 if dtype is not None and is_dtype_equal(_o_dtype, dtype): 

336 # GH#23524 passing `dtype=object` to DatetimeIndex is invalid, 

337 # will raise in the where `data` is already tz-aware. So 

338 # we leave it out of this step and cast to object-dtype after 

339 # the DatetimeIndex construction. 

340 # Note we can pass copy=False because the .astype below 

341 # will always make a copy 

342 result = DatetimeIndex(data, copy=False, name=name, **kwargs) 

343 return result.astype(object) 

344 else: 

345 result = DatetimeIndex( 

346 data, copy=copy, name=name, dtype=dtype, **kwargs 

347 ) 

348 return result 

349 

350 elif is_timedelta64_dtype(data) or ( 

351 dtype is not None and is_timedelta64_dtype(dtype) 

352 ): 

353 from pandas import TimedeltaIndex 

354 

355 if dtype is not None and is_dtype_equal(_o_dtype, dtype): 

356 # Note we can pass copy=False because the .astype below 

357 # will always make a copy 

358 result = TimedeltaIndex(data, copy=False, name=name, **kwargs) 

359 return result.astype(object) 

360 else: 

361 result = TimedeltaIndex( 

362 data, copy=copy, name=name, dtype=dtype, **kwargs 

363 ) 

364 return result 

365 

366 elif is_period_dtype(data) and not is_object_dtype(dtype): 

367 from pandas import PeriodIndex 

368 

369 result = PeriodIndex(data, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs) 

370 return result 

371 

372 # extension dtype 

373 elif is_extension_array_dtype(data) or is_extension_array_dtype(dtype): 

374 data = np.asarray(data) 

375 if not (dtype is None or is_object_dtype(dtype)): 

376 

377 # coerce to the provided dtype 

378 data = dtype.construct_array_type()._from_sequence( 

379 data, dtype=dtype, copy=False 

380 ) 

381 

382 # coerce to the object dtype 

383 data = data.astype(object) 

384 return Index(data, dtype=object, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs) 

385 

386 # index-like 

387 elif isinstance(data, (np.ndarray, Index, ABCSeries)): 

388 if dtype is not None: 

389 try: 

390 

391 # we need to avoid having numpy coerce 

392 # things that look like ints/floats to ints unless 

393 # they are actually ints, e.g. '0' and 0.0 

394 # should not be coerced 

395 # GH 11836 

396 if is_integer_dtype(dtype): 

397 inferred = lib.infer_dtype(data, skipna=False) 

398 if inferred == "integer": 

399 data = maybe_cast_to_integer_array(data, dtype, copy=copy) 

400 elif inferred in ["floating", "mixed-integer-float"]: 

401 if isna(data).any(): 

402 raise ValueError( 

403 "cannot convert float " "NaN to integer" 

404 ) 

405 

406 if inferred == "mixed-integer-float": 

407 data = maybe_cast_to_integer_array(data, dtype) 

408 

409 # If we are actually all equal to integers, 

410 # then coerce to integer. 

411 try: 

412 return cls._try_convert_to_int_index( 

413 data, copy, name, dtype 

414 ) 

415 except ValueError: 

416 pass 

417 

418 # Return an actual float index. 

419 from .numeric import Float64Index 

420 

421 return Float64Index(data, copy=copy, dtype=dtype, name=name) 

422 

423 elif inferred == "string": 

424 pass 

425 else: 

426 data = data.astype(dtype) 

427 elif is_float_dtype(dtype): 

428 inferred = lib.infer_dtype(data, skipna=False) 

429 if inferred == "string": 

430 pass 

431 else: 

432 data = data.astype(dtype) 

433 else: 

434 data = np.array(data, dtype=dtype, copy=copy) 

435 

436 except (TypeError, ValueError) as e: 

437 msg = str(e) 

438 if ( 

439 "cannot convert float" in msg 

440 or "Trying to coerce float values to integer" in msg 

441 ): 

442 raise 

443 

444 # maybe coerce to a sub-class 

445 from pandas.core.indexes.period import PeriodIndex, IncompatibleFrequency 

446 

447 if is_signed_integer_dtype(data.dtype): 

448 from .numeric import Int64Index 

449 

450 return Int64Index(data, copy=copy, dtype=dtype, name=name) 

451 elif is_unsigned_integer_dtype(data.dtype): 

452 from .numeric import UInt64Index 

453 

454 return UInt64Index(data, copy=copy, dtype=dtype, name=name) 

455 elif is_float_dtype(data.dtype): 

456 from .numeric import Float64Index 

457 

458 return Float64Index(data, copy=copy, dtype=dtype, name=name) 

459 elif issubclass(data.dtype.type, np.bool) or is_bool_dtype(data): 

460 subarr = data.astype("object") 

461 else: 

462 subarr = com.asarray_tuplesafe(data, dtype=object) 

463 

464 # asarray_tuplesafe does not always copy underlying data, 

465 # so need to make sure that this happens 

466 if copy: 

467 subarr = subarr.copy() 

468 

469 if dtype is None: 

470 inferred = lib.infer_dtype(subarr, skipna=False) 

471 if inferred == "integer": 

472 try: 

473 return cls._try_convert_to_int_index(subarr, copy, name, dtype) 

474 except ValueError: 

475 pass 

476 

477 return Index(subarr, copy=copy, dtype=object, name=name) 

478 elif inferred in ["floating", "mixed-integer-float"]: 

479 from .numeric import Float64Index 

480 

481 return Float64Index(subarr, copy=copy, name=name) 

482 elif inferred == "interval": 

483 from .interval import IntervalIndex 

484 

485 try: 

486 return IntervalIndex(subarr, name=name, copy=copy) 

487 except ValueError: 

488 # GH27172: mixed closed Intervals --> object dtype 

489 pass 

490 elif inferred == "boolean": 

491 # don't support boolean explicitly ATM 

492 pass 

493 elif inferred != "string": 

494 if inferred.startswith("datetime"): 

495 from pandas import DatetimeIndex 

496 

497 try: 

498 return DatetimeIndex(subarr, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs) 

499 except (ValueError, OutOfBoundsDatetime): 

500 # GH 27011 

501 # If we have mixed timezones, just send it 

502 # down the base constructor 

503 pass 

504 

505 elif inferred.startswith("timedelta"): 

506 from pandas import TimedeltaIndex 

507 

508 return TimedeltaIndex(subarr, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs) 

509 elif inferred == "period": 

510 try: 

511 return PeriodIndex(subarr, name=name, **kwargs) 

512 except IncompatibleFrequency: 

513 pass 

514 return cls._simple_new(subarr, name) 

515 

516 elif hasattr(data, "__array__"): 

517 return Index(np.asarray(data), dtype=dtype, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs) 

518 elif data is None or is_scalar(data): 

519 cls._scalar_data_error(data) 

520 else: 

521 if tupleize_cols and is_list_like(data): 

522 # GH21470: convert iterable to list before determining if empty 

523 if is_iterator(data): 

524 data = list(data) 

525 

526 if data and all(isinstance(e, tuple) for e in data): 

527 # we must be all tuples, otherwise don't construct 

528 # 10697 

529 from .multi import MultiIndex 

530 

531 return MultiIndex.from_tuples( 

532 data, names=name or kwargs.get("names") 

533 ) 

534 # other iterable of some kind 

535 subarr = com.asarray_tuplesafe(data, dtype=object) 

536 return Index(subarr, dtype=dtype, copy=copy, name=name, **kwargs)

538 """ 

539 NOTE for new Index creation: 

540 

541 - _simple_new: It returns new Index with the same type as the caller. 

542 All metadata (such as name) must be provided by caller's responsibility. 

543 Using _shallow_copy is recommended because it fills these metadata 

544 otherwise specified. 

545 

546 - _shallow_copy: It returns new Index with the same type (using 

547 _simple_new), but fills caller's metadata otherwise specified. Passed 

548 kwargs will overwrite corresponding metadata. 

549 

550 - _shallow_copy_with_infer: It returns new Index inferring its type 

551 from passed values. It fills caller's metadata otherwise specified as the 

552 same as _shallow_copy. 

553 

554 See each method's docstring. 

555 """ 

556 

557 @property 

558 def asi8(self): 

559 """ 

560 Integer representation of the values. 

561 

562 Returns 

563 ------- 

564 ndarray 

565 An ndarray with int64 dtype. 

566 """ 

567 return None 

568 

569 @classmethod 

570 def _simple_new(cls, values, name=None, dtype=None, **kwargs): 

571 """ 

572 We require that we have a dtype compat for the values. If we are passed 

573 a non-dtype compat, then coerce using the constructor. 

574 

575 Must be careful not to recurse. 

576 """ 

577 if not hasattr(values, "dtype"): 

578 if (values is None or not len(values)) and dtype is not None: 

579 values = np.empty(0, dtype=dtype) 

580 else: 

581 values = np.array(values, copy=False) 

582 if is_object_dtype(values): 

583 values = cls( 

584 values, name=name, dtype=dtype, **kwargs 

585 )._ndarray_values 

586 

587 if isinstance(values, (ABCSeries, ABCIndexClass)): 

588 # Index._data must always be an ndarray. 

589 # This is no-copy for when _values is an ndarray, 

590 # which should be always at this point. 

591 values = np.asarray(values._values) 

592 

593 result = object.__new__(cls) 

594 result._data = values 

595 # _index_data is a (temporary?) fix to ensure that the direct data 

596 # manipulation we do in `_libs/reduction.pyx` continues to work. 

597 # We need access to the actual ndarray, since we're messing with 

598 # data buffers and strides. We don't re-use `_ndarray_values`, since 

599 # we actually set this value too. 

600 result._index_data = values 

601 result.name = name 

602 for k, v in kwargs.items(): 

603 setattr(result, k, v) 

604 return result._reset_identity() 

605 

606 @cache_readonly 

607 def _constructor(self): 

608 return type(self)

612 

613 def _get_attributes_dict(self): 

614 """ 

615 Return an attributes dict for my class. 

616 """ 

617 return {k: getattr(self, k, None) for k in self._attributes} 

618 

619 _index_shared_docs[ 

620 "_shallow_copy" 

621 ] = """ 

622 Create a new Index with the same class as the caller, don't copy the 

623 data, use the same object attributes with passed in attributes taking 

624 precedence. 

625 

626 *this is an internal non-public method* 

627 

628 Parameters 

629 ---------- 

630 values : the values to create the new Index, optional 

631 kwargs : updates the default attributes for this Index 

632 """ 

633 

634 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["_shallow_copy"]) 

635 def _shallow_copy(self, values=None, **kwargs): 

636 if values is None: 

637 values = self.values 

638 attributes = self._get_attributes_dict() 

639 attributes.update(kwargs) 

640 if not len(values) and "dtype" not in kwargs: 

641 attributes["dtype"] = self.dtype 

642 

643 # _simple_new expects an the type of self._data 

644 values = getattr(values, "_values", values) 

645 if isinstance(values, ABCDatetimeArray): 

646 # `self.values` returns `self` for tz-aware, so we need to unwrap 

647 # more specifically 

648 values = values.asi8 

649 

650 return self._simple_new(values, **attributes) 

651 

652 def _shallow_copy_with_infer(self, values, **kwargs): 

653 """ 

654 Create a new Index inferring the class with passed value, don't copy 

655 the data, use the same object attributes with passed in attributes 

656 taking precedence. 

657 

658 *this is an internal non-public method* 

659 

660 Parameters 

661 ---------- 

662 values : the values to create the new Index, optional 

663 kwargs : updates the default attributes for this Index 

664 """ 

665 attributes = self._get_attributes_dict() 

666 attributes.update(kwargs) 

667 attributes["copy"] = False 

668 if not len(values) and "dtype" not in kwargs: 

669 attributes["dtype"] = self.dtype 

670 if self._infer_as_myclass: 

671 try: 

672 return self._constructor(values, **attributes) 

673 except (TypeError, ValueError): 

674 pass 

675 return Index(values, **attributes) 

676 

677 def _update_inplace(self, result, **kwargs): 

678 # guard when called from IndexOpsMixin 

679 raise TypeError("Index can't be updated inplace") 

680 

681 def is_(self, other): 

682 """ 

683 More flexible, faster check like ``is`` but that works through views. 

684 

685 Note: this is *not* the same as ``Index.identical()``, which checks 

686 that metadata is also the same. 

687 

688 Parameters 

689 ---------- 

690 other : object 

691 other object to compare against. 

692 

693 Returns 

694 ------- 

695 True if both have same underlying data, False otherwise : bool 

696 """ 

697 # use something other than None to be clearer 

698 return self._id is getattr(other, "_id", Ellipsis) and self._id is not None 

699 

700 def _reset_identity(self): 

701 """ 

702 Initializes or resets ``_id`` attribute with new object. 

703 """ 

704 self._id = _Identity() 

705 return self 

706 

707 def _cleanup(self): 

708 self._engine.clear_mapping() 

709 

710 @cache_readonly 

711 def _engine(self): 

712 # property, for now, slow to look up 

713 

714 # to avoid a reference cycle, bind `_ndarray_values` to a local variable, so 

715 # `self` is not passed into the lambda. 

716 _ndarray_values = self._ndarray_values 

717 return self._engine_type(lambda: _ndarray_values, len(self)) 

718 

719 # -------------------------------------------------------------------- 

720 # Array-Like Methods 

721 

722 # ndarray compat 

723 def __len__(self): 

724 """ 

725 Return the length of the Index. 

726 """ 

727 return len(self._data) 

728 

729 def __array__(self, dtype=None): 

730 """ 

731 The array interface, return my values. 

732 """ 

733 return np.asarray(self._data, dtype=dtype) 

734 

735 def __array_wrap__(self, result, context=None): 

736 """ 

737 Gets called after a ufunc. 

738 """ 

739 result = lib.item_from_zerodim(result) 

740 if is_bool_dtype(result) or lib.is_scalar(result): 

741 return result 

742 

743 attrs = self._get_attributes_dict() 

744 attrs = self._maybe_update_attributes(attrs) 

745 return Index(result, **attrs) 

746 

747 @cache_readonly 

748 def dtype(self): 

749 """ 

750 Return the dtype object of the underlying data. 

751 """ 

752 return self._data.dtype 

753 

754 @property 

755 def dtype_str(self): 

756 """ 

757 Return the dtype str of the underlying data. 

758 

759 .. deprecated:: 0.25.0 

760 """ 

761 warnings.warn( 

762 "`dtype_str` has been deprecated. Call `str` on the " 

763 "dtype attribute instead.", 

764 FutureWarning, 

765 stacklevel=2, 

766 ) 

767 return str(self.dtype) 

768 

769 def ravel(self, order="C"): 

770 """ 

771 Return an ndarray of the flattened values of the underlying data. 

772 

773 Returns 

774 ------- 

775 numpy.ndarray 

776 Flattened array. 

777 

778 See Also 

779 -------- 

780 numpy.ndarray.ravel 

781 """ 

782 return self._ndarray_values.ravel(order=order) 

783 

784 def view(self, cls=None): 

785 

786 # we need to see if we are subclassing an 

787 # index type here 

788 if cls is not None and not hasattr(cls, "_typ"): 

789 result = self._data.view(cls) 

790 else: 

791 result = self._shallow_copy() 

792 if isinstance(result, Index): 

793 result._id = self._id 

794 return result

796 _index_shared_docs[ 

797 "astype" 

798 ] = """ 

799 Create an Index with values cast to dtypes. The class of a new Index 

800 is determined by dtype. When conversion is impossible, a ValueError 

801 exception is raised. 

802 

803 Parameters 

804 ---------- 

805 dtype : numpy dtype or pandas type 

806 Note that any signed integer `dtype` is treated as ``'int64'``, 

807 and any unsigned integer `dtype` is treated as ``'uint64'``, 

808 regardless of the size. 

809 copy : bool, default True 

810 By default, astype always returns a newly allocated object. 

811 If copy is set to False and internal requirements on dtype are 

812 satisfied, the original data is used to create a new Index 

813 or the original Index is returned. 

814 

815 .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 

816 

817 Returns 

818 ------- 

819 Index 

820 Index with values cast to specified dtype. 

821 """ 

822 

823 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["astype"]) 

824 def astype(self, dtype, copy=True): 

825 if is_dtype_equal(self.dtype, dtype): 

826 return self.copy() if copy else self 

827 

828 elif is_categorical_dtype(dtype): 

829 from .category import CategoricalIndex 

830 

831 return CategoricalIndex(self.values, name=self.name, dtype=dtype, copy=copy) 

832 elif is_datetime64tz_dtype(dtype): 

833 # TODO(GH-24559): Remove this block, use the following elif. 

834 # avoid FutureWarning from DatetimeIndex constructor. 

835 from pandas import DatetimeIndex 

836 

837 tz = pandas_dtype(dtype).tz 

838 return DatetimeIndex(np.asarray(self)).tz_localize("UTC").tz_convert(tz) 

839 

840 elif is_extension_array_dtype(dtype): 

841 return Index(np.asarray(self), dtype=dtype, copy=copy) 

842 

843 try: 

844 if is_datetime64tz_dtype(dtype): 

845 from pandas import DatetimeIndex 

846 

847 return DatetimeIndex( 

848 self.values, name=self.name, dtype=dtype, copy=copy 

849 ) 

850 return Index( 

851 self.values.astype(dtype, copy=copy), name=self.name, dtype=dtype 

852 ) 

853 except (TypeError, ValueError): 

854 msg = "Cannot cast {name} to dtype {dtype}" 

855 raise TypeError(msg.format(name=type(self).__name__, dtype=dtype))

857 _index_shared_docs[ 

858 "take" 

859 ] = """ 

860 Return a new %(klass)s of the values selected by the indices. 

861 

862 For internal compatibility with numpy arrays. 

863 

864 Parameters 

865 ---------- 

866 indices : list 

867 Indices to be taken 

868 axis : int, optional 

869 The axis over which to select values, always 0. 

870 allow_fill : bool, default True 

871 fill_value : bool, default None 

872 If allow_fill=True and fill_value is not None, indices specified by 

873 -1 is regarded as NA. If Index doesn't hold NA, raise ValueError 

874 

875 Returns 

876 ------- 

877 numpy.ndarray 

878 Elements of given indices. 

879 

880 See Also 

881 -------- 

882 numpy.ndarray.take 

883 """ 

884 

885 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["take"] % _index_doc_kwargs) 

886 def take(self, indices, axis=0, allow_fill=True, fill_value=None, **kwargs): 

887 if kwargs: 

888 nv.validate_take(tuple(), kwargs) 

889 indices = ensure_platform_int(indices) 

890 if self._can_hold_na: 

891 taken = self._assert_take_fillable( 

892 self.values, 

893 indices, 

894 allow_fill=allow_fill, 

895 fill_value=fill_value, 

896 na_value=self._na_value, 

897 ) 

898 else: 

899 if allow_fill and fill_value is not None: 

900 msg = "Unable to fill values because {0} cannot contain NA" 

901 raise ValueError(msg.format(self.__class__.__name__)) 

902 taken = self.values.take(indices) 

903 return self._shallow_copy(taken) 

904 

905 def _assert_take_fillable( 

906 self, values, indices, allow_fill=True, fill_value=None, na_value=np.nan 

907 ): 

908 """ 

909 Internal method to handle NA filling of take. 

910 """ 

911 indices = ensure_platform_int(indices) 

912 

913 # only fill if we are passing a non-None fill_value 

914 if allow_fill and fill_value is not None: 

915 if (indices < -1).any(): 

916 msg = ( 

917 "When allow_fill=True and fill_value is not None, " 

918 "all indices must be >= -1" 

919 ) 

920 raise ValueError(msg) 

921 taken = algos.take( 

922 values, indices, allow_fill=allow_fill, fill_value=na_value 

923 ) 

924 else: 

925 taken = values.take(indices) 

926 return taken

976 _index_shared_docs[ 

977 "copy" 

978 ] = """ 

979 Make a copy of this object. Name and dtype sets those attributes on 

980 the new object. 

981 

982 Parameters 

983 ---------- 

984 name : string, optional 

985 deep : boolean, default False 

986 dtype : numpy dtype or pandas type 

987 

988 Returns 

989 ------- 

990 copy : Index 

991 

992 Notes 

993 ----- 

994 In most cases, there should be no functional difference from using 

995 ``deep``, but if ``deep`` is passed it will attempt to deepcopy. 

996 """ 

997 

998 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["copy"]) 

999 def copy(self, name=None, deep=False, dtype=None, **kwargs): 

1000 if deep: 

1001 new_index = self._shallow_copy(self._data.copy()) 

1002 else: 

1003 new_index = self._shallow_copy() 

1004 

1005 names = kwargs.get("names") 

1006 names = self._validate_names(name=name, names=names, deep=deep) 

1007 new_index = new_index.set_names(names) 

1008 

1009 if dtype: 

1010 new_index = new_index.astype(dtype) 

1011 return new_index

1020 memo, default None 

1021 Standard signature. Unused 

1022 """ 

1023 if memo is None: 

1024 memo = {} 

1025 return self.copy(deep=True)

1028 # Rendering Methods 

1029 

1030 def __repr__(self): 

1031 """ 

1032 Return a string representation for this object. 

1033 """ 

1034 klass = self.__class__.__name__ 

1035 data = self._format_data() 

1036 attrs = self._format_attrs() 

1037 space = self._format_space() 

1038 

1039 prepr = (",%s" % space).join("%s=%s" % (k, v) for k, v in attrs) 

1040 

1041 # no data provided, just attributes 

1042 if data is None: 

1043 data = "" 

1044 

1045 res = "%s(%s%s)" % (klass, data, prepr) 

1046 

1047 return res 

1048 

1049 def _format_space(self): 

1050 

1051 # using space here controls if the attributes 

1052 # are line separated or not (the default) 

1053 

1054 # max_seq_items = get_option('display.max_seq_items') 

1055 # if len(self) > max_seq_items: 

1056 # space = "\n%s" % (' ' * (len(klass) + 1)) 

1057 return " " 

1058 

1059 @property 

1060 def _formatter_func(self): 

1061 """ 

1062 Return the formatter function. 

1063 """ 

1064 return default_pprint 

1065 

1066 def _format_data(self, name=None): 

1067 """ 

1068 Return the formatted data as a unicode string. 

1069 """ 

1070 

1071 # do we want to justify (only do so for non-objects) 

1072 is_justify = not ( 

1073 self.inferred_type in ("string", "unicode") 

1074 or ( 

1075 self.inferred_type == "categorical" and is_object_dtype(self.categories) 

1076 ) 

1077 ) 

1078 

1079 return format_object_summary( 

1080 self, self._formatter_func, is_justify=is_justify, name=name 

1081 ) 

1082 

1083 def _format_attrs(self): 

1084 """ 

1085 Return a list of tuples of the (attr,formatted_value). 

1086 """ 

1087 return format_object_attrs(self) 

1088 

1089 def _mpl_repr(self): 

1090 # how to represent ourselves to matplotlib 

1091 return self.values 

1092 

1093 def format(self, name=False, formatter=None, **kwargs): 

1094 """ 

1095 Render a string representation of the Index. 

1096 """ 

1097 header = [] 

1098 if name: 

1099 header.append( 

1100 pprint_thing(self.name, escape_chars=("\t", "\r", "\n")) 

1101 if self.name is not None 

1102 else "" 

1103 ) 

1104 

1105 if formatter is not None: 

1106 return header + list(self.map(formatter)) 

1107 

1108 return self._format_with_header(header, **kwargs) 

1109 

1110 def _format_with_header(self, header, na_rep="NaN", **kwargs): 

1111 values = self.values 

1112 

1113 from pandas.io.formats.format import format_array 

1114 

1115 if is_categorical_dtype(values.dtype): 

1116 values = np.array(values) 

1117 

1118 elif is_object_dtype(values.dtype): 

1119 values = lib.maybe_convert_objects(values, safe=1) 

1120 

1121 if is_object_dtype(values.dtype): 

1122 result = [pprint_thing(x, escape_chars=("\t", "\r", "\n")) for x in values] 

1123 

1124 # could have nans 

1125 mask = isna(values) 

1126 if mask.any(): 

1127 result = np.array(result) 

1128 result[mask] = na_rep 

1129 result = result.tolist() 

1130 

1131 else: 

1132 result = _trim_front(format_array(values, None, justify="left")) 

1133 return header + result 

1134 

1135 def to_native_types(self, slicer=None, **kwargs): 

1136 """ 

1137 Format specified values of `self` and return them. 

1138 

1139 Parameters 

1140 ---------- 

1141 slicer : int, array-like 

1142 An indexer into `self` that specifies which values 

1143 are used in the formatting process. 

1144 kwargs : dict 

1145 Options for specifying how the values should be formatted. 

1146 These options include the following: 

1147 

1148 1) na_rep : str 

1149 The value that serves as a placeholder for NULL values 

1150 2) quoting : bool or None 

1151 Whether or not there are quoted values in `self` 

1152 3) date_format : str 

1153 The format used to represent date-like values 

1154 

1155 Returns 

1156 ------- 

1157 numpy.ndarray 

1158 Formatted values. 

1159 """ 

1160 

1161 values = self 

1162 if slicer is not None: 

1163 values = values[slicer] 

1164 return values._format_native_types(**kwargs) 

1165 

1166 def _format_native_types(self, na_rep="", quoting=None, **kwargs): 

1167 """ 

1168 Actually format specific types of the index. 

1169 """ 

1170 mask = isna(self) 

1171 if not self.is_object() and not quoting: 

1172 values = np.asarray(self).astype(str) 

1173 else: 

1174 values = np.array(self, dtype=object, copy=True) 

1175 

1176 values[mask] = na_rep 

1177 return values 

1178 

1179 def _summary(self, name=None): 

1180 """ 

1181 Return a summarized representation. 

1182 

1183 Parameters 

1184 ---------- 

1185 name : str 

1186 name to use in the summary representation 

1187 

1188 Returns 

1189 ------- 

1190 String with a summarized representation of the index 

1191 """ 

1192 if len(self) > 0: 

1193 head = self[0] 

1194 if hasattr(head, "format") and not isinstance(head, str): 

1195 head = head.format() 

1196 tail = self[-1] 

1197 if hasattr(tail, "format") and not isinstance(tail, str): 

1198 tail = tail.format() 

1199 index_summary = ", %s to %s" % (pprint_thing(head), pprint_thing(tail)) 

1200 else: 

1201 index_summary = "" 

1202 

1203 if name is None: 

1204 name = type(self).__name__ 

1205 return "%s: %s entries%s" % (name, len(self), index_summary) 

1206 

1207 def summary(self, name=None): 

1208 """ 

1209 Return a summarized representation. 

1210 

1211 .. deprecated:: 0.23.0 

1212 """ 

1213 warnings.warn( 

1214 "'summary' is deprecated and will be removed in a " "future version.", 

1215 FutureWarning, 

1216 stacklevel=2, 

1217 ) 

1218 return self._summary(name)

1243 def to_series(self, index=None, name=None): 

1244 """ 

1245 Create a Series with both index and values equal to the index keys 

1246 useful with map for returning an indexer based on an index. 

1247 

1248 Parameters 

1249 ---------- 

1250 index : Index, optional 

1251 index of resulting Series. If None, defaults to original index 

1252 name : string, optional 

1253 name of resulting Series. If None, defaults to name of original 

1254 index 

1255 

1256 Returns 

1257 ------- 

1258 Series : dtype will be based on the type of the Index values. 

1259 """ 

1260 

1261 from pandas import Series 

1262 

1263 if index is None: 

1264 index = self._shallow_copy() 

1265 if name is None: 

1266 name = self.name 

1267 

1268 return Series(self.values.copy(), index=index, name=name)

1270 def to_frame(self, index=True, name=None): 

1271 """ 

1272 Create a DataFrame with a column containing the Index. 

1273 

1274 .. versionadded:: 0.24.0 

1275 

1276 Parameters 

1277 ---------- 

1278 index : boolean, default True 

1279 Set the index of the returned DataFrame as the original Index. 

1280 

1281 name : object, default None 

1282 The passed name should substitute for the index name (if it has 

1283 one). 

1284 

1285 Returns 

1286 ------- 

1287 DataFrame 

1288 DataFrame containing the original Index data. 

1289 

1290 See Also 

1291 -------- 

1292 Index.to_series : Convert an Index to a Series. 

1293 Series.to_frame : Convert Series to DataFrame. 

1294 

1295 Examples 

1296 -------- 

1297 >>> idx = pd.Index(['Ant', 'Bear', 'Cow'], name='animal') 

1298 >>> idx.to_frame() 

1299 animal 

1300 animal 

1301 Ant Ant 

1302 Bear Bear 

1303 Cow Cow 

1304 

1305 By default, the original Index is reused. To enforce a new Index: 

1306 

1307 >>> idx.to_frame(index=False) 

1308 animal 

1309 0 Ant 

1310 1 Bear 

1311 2 Cow 

1312 

1313 To override the name of the resulting column, specify `name`: 

1314 

1315 >>> idx.to_frame(index=False, name='zoo') 

1316 zoo 

1317 0 Ant 

1318 1 Bear 

1319 2 Cow 

1320 """ 

1321 

1322 from pandas import DataFrame 

1323 

1324 if name is None: 

1325 name = self.name or 0 

1326 result = DataFrame({name: self._values.copy()}) 

1327 

1328 if index: 

1329 result.index = self 

1330 return result

1332 # -------------------------------------------------------------------- 

1333 # Name-Centric Methods 

1334 

1335 def _validate_names(self, name=None, names=None, deep=False): 

1336 """ 

1337 Handles the quirks of having a singular 'name' parameter for general 

1338 Index and plural 'names' parameter for MultiIndex. 

1339 """ 

1340 from copy import deepcopy 

1341 

1342 if names is not None and name is not None: 

1343 raise TypeError("Can only provide one of `names` and `name`") 

1344 elif names is None and name is None: 

1345 return deepcopy(self.names) if deep else self.names 

1346 elif names is not None: 

1347 if not is_list_like(names): 

1348 raise TypeError("Must pass list-like as `names`.") 

1349 return names 

1350 else: 

1351 if not is_list_like(name): 

1352 return [name] 

1353 return name 

1354 

1355 def _get_names(self): 

1356 return FrozenList((self.name,)) 

1357 

1358 def _set_names(self, values, level=None): 

1359 """ 

1360 Set new names on index. Each name has to be a hashable type. 

1361 

1362 Parameters 

1363 ---------- 

1364 values : str or sequence 

1365 name(s) to set 

1366 level : int, level name, or sequence of int/level names (default None) 

1367 If the index is a MultiIndex (hierarchical), level(s) to set (None 

1368 for all levels). Otherwise level must be None 

1369 

1370 Raises 

1371 ------ 

1372 TypeError if each name is not hashable. 

1373 """ 

1374 if not is_list_like(values): 

1375 raise ValueError("Names must be a list-like") 

1376 if len(values) != 1: 

1377 raise ValueError("Length of new names must be 1, got %d" % len(values)) 

1378 

1379 # GH 20527 

1380 # All items in 'name' need to be hashable: 

1381 for name in values: 

1382 if not is_hashable(name): 

1383 raise TypeError( 

1384 "{}.name must be a hashable type".format(self.__class__.__name__) 

1385 ) 

1386 self.name = values[0] 

1387 

1388 names = property(fset=_set_names, fget=_get_names) 

1389 

1390 def set_names(self, names, level=None, inplace=False): 

1391 """ 

1392 Set Index or MultiIndex name. 

1393 

1394 Able to set new names partially and by level. 

1395 

1396 Parameters 

1397 ---------- 

1398 names : label or list of label 

1399 Name(s) to set. 

1400 level : int, label or list of int or label, optional 

1401 If the index is a MultiIndex, level(s) to set (None for all 

1402 levels). Otherwise level must be None. 

1403 inplace : bool, default False 

1404 Modifies the object directly, instead of creating a new Index or 

1405 MultiIndex. 

1406 

1407 Returns 

1408 ------- 

1409 Index 

1410 The same type as the caller or None if inplace is True. 

1411 

1412 See Also 

1413 -------- 

1414 Index.rename : Able to set new names without level. 

1415 

1416 Examples 

1417 -------- 

1418 >>> idx = pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]) 

1419 >>> idx 

1420 Int64Index([1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='int64') 

1421 >>> idx.set_names('quarter') 

1422 Int64Index([1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='int64', name='quarter') 

1423 

1424 >>> idx = pd.MultiIndex.from_product([['python', 'cobra'], 

1425 ... [2018, 2019]]) 

1426 >>> idx 

1427 MultiIndex([('python', 2018), 

1428 ('python', 2019), 

1429 ( 'cobra', 2018), 

1430 ( 'cobra', 2019)], 

1431 ) 

1432 >>> idx.set_names(['kind', 'year'], inplace=True) 

1433 >>> idx 

1434 MultiIndex([('python', 2018), 

1435 ('python', 2019), 

1436 ( 'cobra', 2018), 

1437 ( 'cobra', 2019)], 

1438 names=['kind', 'year']) 

1439 >>> idx.set_names('species', level=0) 

1440 MultiIndex([('python', 2018), 

1441 ('python', 2019), 

1442 ( 'cobra', 2018), 

1443 ( 'cobra', 2019)], 

1444 names=['species', 'year']) 

1445 """ 

1446 

1447 if level is not None and not isinstance(self, ABCMultiIndex): 

1448 raise ValueError("Level must be None for non-MultiIndex") 

1449 

1450 if level is not None and not is_list_like(level) and is_list_like(names): 

1451 msg = "Names must be a string when a single level is provided." 

1452 raise TypeError(msg) 

1453 

1454 if not is_list_like(names) and level is None and self.nlevels > 1: 

1455 raise TypeError("Must pass list-like as `names`.") 

1456 

1457 if not is_list_like(names): 

1458 names = [names] 

1459 if level is not None and not is_list_like(level): 

1460 level = [level] 

1461 

1462 if inplace: 

1463 idx = self 

1464 else: 

1465 idx = self._shallow_copy() 

1466 idx._set_names(names, level=level) 

1467 if not inplace: 

1468 return idx 

1469 

1470 def rename(self, name, inplace=False): 

1471 """ 

1472 Alter Index or MultiIndex name. 

1473 

1474 Able to set new names without level. Defaults to returning new index. 

1475 Length of names must match number of levels in MultiIndex. 

1476 

1477 Parameters 

1478 ---------- 

1479 name : label or list of labels 

1480 Name(s) to set. 

1481 inplace : boolean, default False 

1482 Modifies the object directly, instead of creating a new Index or 

1483 MultiIndex. 

1484 

1485 Returns 

1486 ------- 

1487 Index 

1488 The same type as the caller or None if inplace is True. 

1489 

1490 See Also 

1491 -------- 

1492 Index.set_names : Able to set new names partially and by level. 

1493 

1494 Examples 

1495 -------- 

1496 >>> idx = pd.Index(['A', 'C', 'A', 'B'], name='score') 

1497 >>> idx.rename('grade') 

1498 Index(['A', 'C', 'A', 'B'], dtype='object', name='grade') 

1499 

1500 >>> idx = pd.MultiIndex.from_product([['python', 'cobra'], 

1501 ... [2018, 2019]], 

1502 ... names=['kind', 'year']) 

1503 >>> idx 

1504 MultiIndex([('python', 2018), 

1505 ('python', 2019), 

1506 ( 'cobra', 2018), 

1507 ( 'cobra', 2019)], 

1508 names=['kind', 'year']) 

1509 >>> idx.rename(['species', 'year']) 

1510 MultiIndex([('python', 2018), 

1511 ('python', 2019), 

1512 ( 'cobra', 2018), 

1513 ( 'cobra', 2019)], 

1514 names=['species', 'year']) 

1515 >>> idx.rename('species') 

1516 Traceback (most recent call last): 

1517 TypeError: Must pass list-like as `names`. 

1518 """ 

1519 return self.set_names([name], inplace=inplace)

1522 # Level-Centric Methods 

1523 

1524 @property 

1525 def nlevels(self): 

1526 """ 

1527 Number of levels. 

1528 """ 

1529 return 1 

1530 

1531 def _sort_levels_monotonic(self): 

1532 """ 

1533 Compat with MultiIndex. 

1534 """ 

1535 return self 

1536 

1537 def _validate_index_level(self, level): 

1538 """ 

1539 Validate index level. 

1540 

1541 For single-level Index getting level number is a no-op, but some 

1542 verification must be done like in MultiIndex. 

1543 

1544 """ 

1545 if isinstance(level, int): 

1546 if level < 0 and level != -1: 

1547 raise IndexError( 

1548 "Too many levels: Index has only 1 level," 

1549 " %d is not a valid level number" % (level,) 

1550 ) 

1551 elif level > 0: 

1552 raise IndexError( 

1553 "Too many levels:" " Index has only 1 level, not %d" % (level + 1) 

1554 ) 

1555 elif level != self.name: 

1556 raise KeyError( 

1557 "Requested level ({}) does not match index name ({})".format( 

1558 level, self.name 

1559 ) 

1560 ) 

1561 

1562 def _get_level_number(self, level): 

1563 self._validate_index_level(level) 

1564 return 0 

1565 

1566 def sortlevel(self, level=None, ascending=True, sort_remaining=None): 

1567 """ 

1568 For internal compatibility with with the Index API. 

1569 

1570 Sort the Index. This is for compat with MultiIndex 

1571 

1572 Parameters 

1573 ---------- 

1574 ascending : boolean, default True 

1575 False to sort in descending order 

1576 

1577 level, sort_remaining are compat parameters 

1578 

1579 Returns 

1580 ------- 

1581 Index 

1582 """ 

1583 return self.sort_values(return_indexer=True, ascending=ascending) 

1584 

1585 def _get_level_values(self, level): 

1586 """ 

1587 Return an Index of values for requested level. 

1588 

1589 This is primarily useful to get an individual level of values from a 

1590 MultiIndex, but is provided on Index as well for compatibility. 

1591 

1592 Parameters 

1593 ---------- 

1594 level : int or str 

1595 It is either the integer position or the name of the level. 

1596 

1597 Returns 

1598 ------- 

1599 Index 

1600 Calling object, as there is only one level in the Index. 

1601 

1602 See Also 

1603 -------- 

1604 MultiIndex.get_level_values : Get values for a level of a MultiIndex. 

1605 

1606 Notes 

1607 ----- 

1608 For Index, level should be 0, since there are no multiple levels. 

1609 

1610 Examples 

1611 -------- 

1612 

1613 >>> idx = pd.Index(list('abc')) 

1614 >>> idx 

1615 Index(['a', 'b', 'c'], dtype='object') 

1616 

1617 Get level values by supplying `level` as integer: 

1618 

1619 >>> idx.get_level_values(0) 

1620 Index(['a', 'b', 'c'], dtype='object') 

1621 """ 

1622 self._validate_index_level(level) 

1623 return self 

1624 

1625 get_level_values = _get_level_values 

1626 

1627 def droplevel(self, level=0): 

1628 """ 

1629 Return index with requested level(s) removed. 

1630 

1631 If resulting index has only 1 level left, the result will be 

1632 of Index type, not MultiIndex. 

1633 

1634 .. versionadded:: 0.23.1 (support for non-MultiIndex) 

1635 

1636 Parameters 

1637 ---------- 

1638 level : int, str, or list-like, default 0 

1639 If a string is given, must be the name of a level 

1640 If list-like, elements must be names or indexes of levels. 

1641 

1642 Returns 

1643 ------- 

1644 Index or MultiIndex 

1645 """ 

1646 if not isinstance(level, (tuple, list)): 

1647 level = [level] 

1648 

1649 levnums = sorted(self._get_level_number(lev) for lev in level)[::-1] 

1650 

1651 if len(level) == 0: 

1652 return self 

1653 if len(level) >= self.nlevels: 

1654 raise ValueError( 

1655 "Cannot remove {} levels from an index with {} " 

1656 "levels: at least one level must be " 

1657 "left.".format(len(level), self.nlevels) 

1658 ) 

1659 # The two checks above guarantee that here self is a MultiIndex 

1660 

1661 new_levels = list(self.levels) 

1662 new_codes = list(self.codes) 

1663 new_names = list(self.names) 

1664 

1665 for i in levnums: 

1666 new_levels.pop(i) 

1667 new_codes.pop(i) 

1668 new_names.pop(i) 

1669 

1670 if len(new_levels) == 1: 

1671 

1672 # set nan if needed 

1673 mask = new_codes[0] == -1 

1674 result = new_levels[0].take(new_codes[0]) 

1675 if mask.any(): 

1676 result = result.putmask(mask, np.nan) 

1677 

1678 result.name = new_names[0] 

1679 return result 

1680 else: 

1681 from .multi import MultiIndex 

1682 

1683 return MultiIndex( 

1684 levels=new_levels, 

1685 codes=new_codes, 

1686 names=new_names, 

1687 verify_integrity=False, 

1688 ) 

1689 

1690 _index_shared_docs[ 

1691 "_get_grouper_for_level" 

1692 ] = """ 

1693 Get index grouper corresponding to an index level 

1694 

1695 Parameters 

1696 ---------- 

1697 mapper: Group mapping function or None 

1698 Function mapping index values to groups 

1699 level : int or None 

1700 Index level 

1701 

1702 Returns 

1703 ------- 

1704 grouper : Index 

1705 Index of values to group on. 

1706 labels : ndarray of int or None 

1707 Array of locations in level_index. 

1708 uniques : Index or None 

1709 Index of unique values for level. 

1710 """ 

1711 

1712 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["_get_grouper_for_level"]) 

1713 def _get_grouper_for_level(self, mapper, level=None): 

1714 assert level is None or level == 0 

1715 if mapper is None: 

1716 grouper = self 

1717 else: 

1718 grouper = self.map(mapper) 

1719 

1720 return grouper, None, None

1890 # -------------------------------------------------------------------- 

1891 # Pickle Methods 

1892 

1893 def __reduce__(self): 

1894 d = dict(data=self._data) 

1895 d.update(self._get_attributes_dict()) 

1896 return _new_Index, (self.__class__, d), None 

1897 

1898 def __setstate__(self, state): 

1899 """ 

1900 Necessary for making this object picklable. 

1901 """ 

1902 

1903 if isinstance(state, dict): 

1904 self._data = state.pop("data") 

1905 for k, v in state.items(): 

1906 setattr(self, k, v) 

1907 

1908 elif isinstance(state, tuple): 

1909 

1910 if len(state) == 2: 

1911 nd_state, own_state = state 

1912 data = np.empty(nd_state[1], dtype=nd_state[2]) 

1913 np.ndarray.__setstate__(data, nd_state) 

1914 self.name = own_state[0] 

1915 

1916 else: # pragma: no cover 

1917 data = np.empty(state) 

1918 np.ndarray.__setstate__(data, state) 

1919 

1920 self._data = data 

1921 self._reset_identity() 

1922 else: 

1923 raise Exception("invalid pickle state") 

1924 

1925 _unpickle_compat = __setstate__ 

1926 

1927 # -------------------------------------------------------------------- 

1928 # Null Handling Methods 

1929 

1930 _na_value = np.nan 

1931 """The expected NA value to use with this index.""" 

1932 

1933 @cache_readonly 

1934 def _isnan(self): 

1935 """ 

1936 Return if each value is NaN. 

1937 """ 

1938 if self._can_hold_na: 

1939 return isna(self) 

1940 else: 

1941 # shouldn't reach to this condition by checking hasnans beforehand 

1942 values = np.empty(len(self), dtype=np.bool_) 

1943 values.fill(False) 

1944 return values 

1945 

1946 @cache_readonly 

1947 def _nan_idxs(self): 

1948 if self._can_hold_na: 

1949 w, = self._isnan.nonzero() 

1950 return w 

1951 else: 

1952 return np.array([], dtype=np.int64) 

1953 

1954 @cache_readonly 

1955 def hasnans(self): 

1956 """ 

1957 Return if I have any nans; enables various perf speedups. 

1958 """ 

1959 if self._can_hold_na: 

1960 return bool(self._isnan.any()) 

1961 else: 

1962 return False 

1963 

1964 def isna(self): 

1965 """ 

1966 Detect missing values. 

1967 

1968 Return a boolean same-sized object indicating if the values are NA. 

1969 NA values, such as ``None``, :attr:`numpy.NaN` or :attr:`pd.NaT`, get 

1970 mapped to ``True`` values. 

1971 Everything else get mapped to ``False`` values. Characters such as 

1972 empty strings `''` or :attr:`numpy.inf` are not considered NA values 

1973 (unless you set ``pandas.options.mode.use_inf_as_na = True``). 

1974 

1975 .. versionadded:: 0.20.0 

1976 

1977 Returns 

1978 ------- 

1979 numpy.ndarray 

1980 A boolean array of whether my values are NA. 

1981 

1982 See Also 

1983 -------- 

1984 Index.notna : Boolean inverse of isna. 

1985 Index.dropna : Omit entries with missing values. 

1986 isna : Top-level isna. 

1987 Series.isna : Detect missing values in Series object. 

1988 

1989 Examples 

1990 -------- 

1991 Show which entries in a pandas.Index are NA. The result is an 

1992 array. 

1993 

1994 >>> idx = pd.Index([5.2, 6.0, np.NaN]) 

1995 >>> idx 

1996 Float64Index([5.2, 6.0, nan], dtype='float64') 

1997 >>> idx.isna() 

1998 array([False, False, True], dtype=bool) 

1999 

2000 Empty strings are not considered NA values. None is considered an NA 

2001 value. 

2002 

2003 >>> idx = pd.Index(['black', '', 'red', None]) 

2004 >>> idx 

2005 Index(['black', '', 'red', None], dtype='object') 

2006 >>> idx.isna() 

2007 array([False, False, False, True], dtype=bool) 

2008 

2009 For datetimes, `NaT` (Not a Time) is considered as an NA value. 

2010 

2011 >>> idx = pd.DatetimeIndex([pd.Timestamp('1940-04-25'), 

2012 ... pd.Timestamp(''), None, pd.NaT]) 

2013 >>> idx 

2014 DatetimeIndex(['1940-04-25', 'NaT', 'NaT', 'NaT'], 

2015 dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None) 

2016 >>> idx.isna() 

2017 array([False, True, True, True], dtype=bool) 

2018 """ 

2019 return self._isnan 

2020 

2021 isnull = isna 

2022 

2023 def notna(self): 

2024 """ 

2025 Detect existing (non-missing) values. 

2026 

2027 Return a boolean same-sized object indicating if the values are not NA. 

2028 Non-missing values get mapped to ``True``. Characters such as empty 

2029 strings ``''`` or :attr:`numpy.inf` are not considered NA values 

2030 (unless you set ``pandas.options.mode.use_inf_as_na = True``). 

2031 NA values, such as None or :attr:`numpy.NaN`, get mapped to ``False`` 

2032 values. 

2033 

2034 .. versionadded:: 0.20.0 

2035 

2036 Returns 

2037 ------- 

2038 numpy.ndarray 

2039 Boolean array to indicate which entries are not NA. 

2040 

2041 See Also 

2042 -------- 

2043 Index.notnull : Alias of notna. 

2044 Index.isna: Inverse of notna. 

2045 notna : Top-level notna. 

2046 

2047 Examples 

2048 -------- 

2049 Show which entries in an Index are not NA. The result is an 

2050 array. 

2051 

2052 >>> idx = pd.Index([5.2, 6.0, np.NaN]) 

2053 >>> idx 

2054 Float64Index([5.2, 6.0, nan], dtype='float64') 

2055 >>> idx.notna() 

2056 array([ True, True, False]) 

2057 

2058 Empty strings are not considered NA values. None is considered a NA 

2059 value. 

2060 

2061 >>> idx = pd.Index(['black', '', 'red', None]) 

2062 >>> idx 

2063 Index(['black', '', 'red', None], dtype='object') 

2064 >>> idx.notna() 

2065 array([ True, True, True, False]) 

2066 """ 

2067 return ~self.isna() 

2068 

2069 notnull = notna 

2070 

2071 _index_shared_docs[ 

2072 "fillna" 

2073 ] = """ 

2074 Fill NA/NaN values with the specified value 

2075 

2076 Parameters 

2077 ---------- 

2078 value : scalar 

2079 Scalar value to use to fill holes (e.g. 0). 

2080 This value cannot be a list-likes. 

2081 downcast : dict, default is None 

2082 a dict of item->dtype of what to downcast if possible, 

2083 or the string 'infer' which will try to downcast to an appropriate 

2084 equal type (e.g. float64 to int64 if possible) 

2085 

2086 Returns 

2087 ------- 

2088 filled : Index 

2089 """ 

2090 

2091 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["fillna"]) 

2092 def fillna(self, value=None, downcast=None): 

2093 self._assert_can_do_op(value) 

2094 if self.hasnans: 

2095 result = self.putmask(self._isnan, value) 

2096 if downcast is None: 

2097 # no need to care metadata other than name 

2098 # because it can't have freq if 

2099 return Index(result, name=self.name) 

2100 return self._shallow_copy() 

2101 

2102 _index_shared_docs[ 

2103 "dropna" 

2104 ] = """ 

2105 Return Index without NA/NaN values 

2106 

2107 Parameters 

2108 ---------- 

2109 how : {'any', 'all'}, default 'any' 

2110 If the Index is a MultiIndex, drop the value when any or all levels 

2111 are NaN. 

2112 

2113 Returns 

2114 ------- 

2115 valid : Index 

2116 """ 

2117 

2118 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["dropna"]) 

2119 def dropna(self, how="any"): 

2120 if how not in ("any", "all"): 

2121 raise ValueError("invalid how option: {0}".format(how)) 

2122 

2123 if self.hasnans: 

2124 return self._shallow_copy(self.values[~self._isnan]) 

2125 return self._shallow_copy()

2138 level : int or str, optional, default None

2152 

2153 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["index_unique"] % _index_doc_kwargs) 

2154 def unique(self, level=None): 

2155 if level is not None: 

2156 self._validate_index_level(level) 

2157 result = super().unique()

2159 

2160 def drop_duplicates(self, keep="first"): 

2161 """ 

2162 Return Index with duplicate values removed. 

2163 

2164 Parameters 

2165 ---------- 

2166 keep : {'first', 'last', ``False``}, default 'first' 

2167 - 'first' : Drop duplicates except for the first occurrence. 

2168 - 'last' : Drop duplicates except for the last occurrence. 

2169 - ``False`` : Drop all duplicates. 

2170 

2171 Returns 

2172 ------- 

2173 deduplicated : Index 

2174 

2175 See Also 

2176 -------- 

2177 Series.drop_duplicates : Equivalent method on Series. 

2178 DataFrame.drop_duplicates : Equivalent method on DataFrame. 

2179 Index.duplicated : Related method on Index, indicating duplicate 

2180 Index values. 

2181 

2182 Examples 

2183 -------- 

2184 Generate an pandas.Index with duplicate values. 

2185 

2186 >>> idx = pd.Index(['lama', 'cow', 'lama', 'beetle', 'lama', 'hippo']) 

2187 

2188 The `keep` parameter controls which duplicate values are removed. 

2189 The value 'first' keeps the first occurrence for each 

2190 set of duplicated entries. The default value of keep is 'first'. 

2191 

2192 >>> idx.drop_duplicates(keep='first') 

2193 Index(['lama', 'cow', 'beetle', 'hippo'], dtype='object') 

2194 

2195 The value 'last' keeps the last occurrence for each set of duplicated 

2196 entries. 

2197 

2198 >>> idx.drop_duplicates(keep='last') 

2199 Index(['cow', 'beetle', 'lama', 'hippo'], dtype='object') 

2200 

2201 The value ``False`` discards all sets of duplicated entries. 

2202 

2203 >>> idx.drop_duplicates(keep=False) 

2204 Index(['cow', 'beetle', 'hippo'], dtype='object') 

2205 """ 

2206 return super().drop_duplicates(keep=keep) 

2207 

2208 def duplicated(self, keep="first"): 

2209 """ 

2210 Indicate duplicate index values. 

2211 

2212 Duplicated values are indicated as ``True`` values in the resulting 

2213 array. Either all duplicates, all except the first, or all except the 

2214 last occurrence of duplicates can be indicated. 

2215 

2216 Parameters 

2217 ---------- 

2218 keep : {'first', 'last', False}, default 'first' 

2219 The value or values in a set of duplicates to mark as missing. 

2220 

2221 - 'first' : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the first 

2222 occurrence. 

2223 - 'last' : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the last 

2224 occurrence. 

2225 - ``False`` : Mark all duplicates as ``True``. 

2226 

2227 Returns 

2228 ------- 

2229 numpy.ndarray 

2230 

2231 See Also 

2232 -------- 

2233 Series.duplicated : Equivalent method on pandas.Series. 

2234 DataFrame.duplicated : Equivalent method on pandas.DataFrame. 

2235 Index.drop_duplicates : Remove duplicate values from Index. 

2236 

2237 Examples 

2238 -------- 

2239 By default, for each set of duplicated values, the first occurrence is 

2240 set to False and all others to True: 

2241 

2242 >>> idx = pd.Index(['lama', 'cow', 'lama', 'beetle', 'lama']) 

2243 >>> idx.duplicated() 

2244 array([False, False, True, False, True]) 

2245 

2246 which is equivalent to 

2247 

2248 >>> idx.duplicated(keep='first') 

2249 array([False, False, True, False, True]) 

2250 

2251 By using 'last', the last occurrence of each set of duplicated values 

2252 is set on False and all others on True: 

2253 

2254 >>> idx.duplicated(keep='last') 

2255 array([ True, False, True, False, False]) 

2256 

2257 By setting keep on ``False``, all duplicates are True: 

2258 

2259 >>> idx.duplicated(keep=False) 

2260 array([ True, False, True, False, True]) 

2261 """ 

2262 return super().duplicated(keep=keep) 

2263 

2264 def get_duplicates(self): 

2265 """ 

2266 Extract duplicated index elements. 

2267 

2268 .. deprecated:: 0.23.0 

2269 Use idx[idx.duplicated()].unique() instead 

2270 

2271 Returns a sorted list of index elements which appear more than once in 

2272 the index. 

2273 

2274 Returns 

2275 ------- 

2276 array-like 

2277 List of duplicated indexes. 

2278 

2279 See Also 

2280 -------- 

2281 Index.duplicated : Return boolean array denoting duplicates. 

2282 Index.drop_duplicates : Return Index with duplicates removed. 

2283 

2284 Examples 

2285 -------- 

2286 

2287 Works on different Index of types. 

2288 

2289 >>> pd.Index([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4]).get_duplicates() # doctest: +SKIP 

2290 [2, 3] 

2291 

2292 Note that for a DatetimeIndex, it does not return a list but a new 

2293 DatetimeIndex: 

2294 

2295 >>> dates = pd.to_datetime(['2018-01-01', '2018-01-02', '2018-01-03', 

2296 ... '2018-01-03', '2018-01-04', '2018-01-04'], 

2297 ... format='%Y-%m-%d') 

2298 >>> pd.Index(dates).get_duplicates() # doctest: +SKIP 

2299 DatetimeIndex(['2018-01-03', '2018-01-04'], 

2300 dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None) 

2301 

2302 Sorts duplicated elements even when indexes are unordered. 

2303 

2304 >>> pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 3]).get_duplicates() # doctest: +SKIP 

2305 [2, 3] 

2306 

2307 Return empty array-like structure when all elements are unique. 

2308 

2309 >>> pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]).get_duplicates() # doctest: +SKIP 

2310 [] 

2311 >>> dates = pd.to_datetime(['2018-01-01', '2018-01-02', '2018-01-03'], 

2312 ... format='%Y-%m-%d') 

2313 >>> pd.Index(dates).get_duplicates() # doctest: +SKIP 

2314 DatetimeIndex([], dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None) 

2315 """ 

2316 warnings.warn( 

2317 "'get_duplicates' is deprecated and will be removed in " 

2318 "a future release. You can use " 

2319 "idx[idx.duplicated()].unique() instead", 

2320 FutureWarning, 

2321 stacklevel=2, 

2322 ) 

2323 

2324 return self[self.duplicated()].unique() 

2325 

2326 def _get_unique_index(self, dropna=False): 

2327 """ 

2328 Returns an index containing unique values. 

2329 

2330 Parameters 

2331 ---------- 

2332 dropna : bool 

2333 If True, NaN values are dropped. 

2334 

2335 Returns 

2336 ------- 

2337 uniques : index 

2338 """ 

2339 if self.is_unique and not dropna: 

2340 return self 

2341 

2342 values = self.values 

2343 

2344 if not self.is_unique: 

2345 values = self.unique() 

2346 

2347 if dropna: 

2348 try: 

2349 if self.hasnans: 

2350 values = values[~isna(values)] 

2351 except NotImplementedError: 

2352 pass 

2353 

2354 return self._shallow_copy(values)

2359 def __add__(self, other): 

2360 if isinstance(other, (ABCSeries, ABCDataFrame)): 

2361 return NotImplemented 

2362 from pandas import Series 

2363 

2364 return Index(Series(self) + other) 

2365 

2366 def __radd__(self, other): 

2367 from pandas import Series 

2368 

2369 return Index(other + Series(self)) 

2370 

2371 def __iadd__(self, other): 

2372 # alias for __add__ 

2373 return self + other 

2374 

2375 def __sub__(self, other): 

2376 return Index(np.array(self) - other) 

2377 

2378 def __rsub__(self, other): 

2379 return Index(other - np.array(self)) 

2380 

2381 def __and__(self, other): 

2382 return self.intersection(other) 

2383 

2384 def __or__(self, other): 

2385 return self.union(other) 

2386 

2387 def __xor__(self, other): 

2388 return self.symmetric_difference(other)

2391 raise ValueError( 

2392 "The truth value of a {0} is ambiguous. " 

2393 "Use a.empty, a.bool(), a.item(), a.any() or a.all().".format( 

2394 self.__class__.__name__ 

2395 ) 

2396 ) 

2397 

2398 __bool__ = __nonzero__

2403 def _get_reconciled_name_object(self, other): 

2404 """ 

2405 If the result of a set operation will be self, 

2406 return self, unless the name changes, in which 

2407 case make a shallow copy of self. 

2408 """ 

2409 name = get_op_result_name(self, other) 

2410 if self.name != name: 

2411 return self._shallow_copy(name=name) 

2412 return self 

2413 

2414 def _union_incompatible_dtypes(self, other, sort): 

2415 """ 

2416 Casts this and other index to object dtype to allow the formation 

2417 of a union between incompatible types. 

2418 

2419 Parameters 

2420 ---------- 

2421 other : Index or array-like 

2422 sort : False or None, default False 

2423 Whether to sort the resulting index. 

2424 

2425 * False : do not sort the result. 

2426 * None : sort the result, except when `self` and `other` are equal 

2427 or when the values cannot be compared. 

2428 

2429 Returns 

2430 ------- 

2431 Index 

2432 """ 

2433 this = self.astype(object, copy=False) 

2434 # cast to Index for when `other` is list-like 

2435 other = Index(other).astype(object, copy=False) 

2436 return Index.union(this, other, sort=sort).astype(object, copy=False) 

2437 

2438 def _is_compatible_with_other(self, other): 

2439 """ 

2440 Check whether this and the other dtype are compatible with each other. 

2441 Meaning a union can be formed between them without needing to be cast 

2442 to dtype object. 

2443 

2444 Parameters 

2445 ---------- 

2446 other : Index or array-like 

2447 

2448 Returns 

2449 ------- 

2450 bool 

2451 """ 

2452 return type(self) is type(other) and is_dtype_equal(self.dtype, other.dtype) 

2453 

2454 def _validate_sort_keyword(self, sort): 

2455 if sort not in [None, False]: 

2456 raise ValueError( 

2457 "The 'sort' keyword only takes the values of " 

2458 "None or False; {0} was passed.".format(sort) 

2459 )

2461 def union(self, other, sort=None): 

2462 """ 

2463 Form the union of two Index objects. 

2464 

2465 If the Index objects are incompatible, both Index objects will be 

2466 cast to dtype('object') first. 

2467 

2468 .. versionchanged:: 0.25.0 

2469 

2470 Parameters 

2471 ---------- 

2472 other : Index or array-like 

2473 sort : bool or None, default None 

2474 Whether to sort the resulting Index. 

2475 

2476 * None : Sort the result, except when 

2477 

2478 1. `self` and `other` are equal. 

2479 2. `self` or `other` has length 0. 

2480 3. Some values in `self` or `other` cannot be compared. 

2481 A RuntimeWarning is issued in this case. 

2482 

2483 * False : do not sort the result. 

2484 

2485 .. versionadded:: 0.24.0 

2486 

2487 .. versionchanged:: 0.24.1 

2488 

2489 Changed the default value from ``True`` to ``None`` 

2490 (without change in behaviour). 

2491 

2492 Returns 

2493 ------- 

2494 union : Index 

2495 

2496 Examples 

2497 -------- 

2498 

2499 Union matching dtypes 

2500 

2501 >>> idx1 = pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2502 >>> idx2 = pd.Index([3, 4, 5, 6]) 

2503 >>> idx1.union(idx2) 

2504 Int64Index([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6], dtype='int64') 

2505 

2506 Union mismatched dtypes 

2507 

2508 >>> idx1 = pd.Index(['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']) 

2509 >>> idx2 = pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2510 >>> idx1.union(idx2) 

2511 Index(['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='object') 

2512 """ 

2513 self._validate_sort_keyword(sort) 

2514 self._assert_can_do_setop(other) 

2515 

2516 if not self._is_compatible_with_other(other): 

2517 return self._union_incompatible_dtypes(other, sort=sort) 

2518 

2519 return self._union(other, sort=sort) 

2520 

2521 def _union(self, other, sort): 

2522 """ 

2523 Specific union logic should go here. In subclasses, union behavior 

2524 should be overwritten here rather than in `self.union`. 

2525 

2526 Parameters 

2527 ---------- 

2528 other : Index or array-like 

2529 sort : False or None, default False 

2530 Whether to sort the resulting index. 

2531 

2532 * False : do not sort the result. 

2533 * None : sort the result, except when `self` and `other` are equal 

2534 or when the values cannot be compared. 

2535 

2536 Returns 

2537 ------- 

2538 Index 

2539 """ 

2540 

2541 if not len(other) or self.equals(other): 

2542 return self._get_reconciled_name_object(other) 

2543 

2544 if not len(self): 

2545 return other._get_reconciled_name_object(self) 

2546 

2547 # TODO(EA): setops-refactor, clean all this up 

2548 if is_period_dtype(self) or is_datetime64tz_dtype(self): 

2549 lvals = self._ndarray_values 

2550 else: 

2551 lvals = self._values 

2552 if is_period_dtype(other) or is_datetime64tz_dtype(other): 

2553 rvals = other._ndarray_values 

2554 else: 

2555 rvals = other._values 

2556 

2557 if sort is None and self.is_monotonic and other.is_monotonic: 

2558 try: 

2559 result = self._outer_indexer(lvals, rvals)[0] 

2560 except TypeError: 

2561 # incomparable objects 

2562 result = list(lvals) 

2563 

2564 # worth making this faster? a very unusual case 

2565 value_set = set(lvals) 

2566 result.extend([x for x in rvals if x not in value_set]) 

2567 else: 

2568 indexer = self.get_indexer(other) 

2569 indexer, = (indexer == -1).nonzero() 

2570 

2571 if len(indexer) > 0: 

2572 other_diff = algos.take_nd(rvals, indexer, allow_fill=False) 

2573 result = _concat._concat_compat((lvals, other_diff)) 

2574 

2575 else: 

2576 result = lvals 

2577 

2578 if sort is None: 

2579 try: 

2580 result = sorting.safe_sort(result) 

2581 except TypeError as e: 

2582 warnings.warn( 

2583 "{}, sort order is undefined for " 

2584 "incomparable objects".format(e), 

2585 RuntimeWarning, 

2586 stacklevel=3, 

2587 ) 

2588 

2589 # for subclasses 

2590 return self._wrap_setop_result(other, result) 

2591 

2592 def _wrap_setop_result(self, other, result): 

2593 return self._constructor(result, name=get_op_result_name(self, other)) 

2594 

2595 _index_shared_docs[ 

2596 "intersection" 

2597 ] = """ 

2598 Form the intersection of two Index objects. 

2599 

2600 This returns a new Index with elements common to the index and `other`. 

2601 

2602 Parameters 

2603 ---------- 

2604 other : Index or array-like 

2605 sort : False or None, default False 

2606 Whether to sort the resulting index. 

2607 

2608 * False : do not sort the result. 

2609 * None : sort the result, except when `self` and `other` are equal 

2610 or when the values cannot be compared. 

2611 

2612 .. versionadded:: 0.24.0 

2613 

2614 .. versionchanged:: 0.24.1 

2615 

2616 Changed the default from ``True`` to ``False``, to match 

2617 the behaviour of 0.23.4 and earlier. 

2618 

2619 Returns 

2620 ------- 

2621 intersection : Index 

2622 

2623 Examples 

2624 -------- 

2625 

2626 >>> idx1 = pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2627 >>> idx2 = pd.Index([3, 4, 5, 6]) 

2628 >>> idx1.intersection(idx2) 

2629 Int64Index([3, 4], dtype='int64') 

2630 """ 

2631 

2632 # TODO: standardize return type of non-union setops type(self vs other) 

2633 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["intersection"]) 

2634 def intersection(self, other, sort=False): 

2635 self._validate_sort_keyword(sort) 

2636 self._assert_can_do_setop(other) 

2637 other = ensure_index(other) 

2638 

2639 if self.equals(other): 

2640 return self._get_reconciled_name_object(other) 

2641 

2642 if not is_dtype_equal(self.dtype, other.dtype): 

2643 this = self.astype("O") 

2644 other = other.astype("O") 

2645 return this.intersection(other, sort=sort) 

2646 

2647 # TODO(EA): setops-refactor, clean all this up 

2648 if is_period_dtype(self): 

2649 lvals = self._ndarray_values 

2650 else: 

2651 lvals = self._values 

2652 if is_period_dtype(other): 

2653 rvals = other._ndarray_values 

2654 else: 

2655 rvals = other._values 

2656 

2657 if self.is_monotonic and other.is_monotonic: 

2658 try: 

2659 result = self._inner_indexer(lvals, rvals)[0] 

2660 return self._wrap_setop_result(other, result) 

2661 except TypeError: 

2662 pass 

2663 

2664 try: 

2665 indexer = Index(rvals).get_indexer(lvals) 

2666 indexer = indexer.take((indexer != -1).nonzero()[0]) 

2667 except Exception: 

2668 # duplicates 

2669 indexer = algos.unique1d(Index(rvals).get_indexer_non_unique(lvals)[0]) 

2670 indexer = indexer[indexer != -1] 

2671 

2672 taken = other.take(indexer) 

2673 

2674 if sort is None: 

2675 taken = sorting.safe_sort(taken.values) 

2676 if self.name != other.name: 

2677 name = None 

2678 else: 

2679 name = self.name 

2680 return self._shallow_copy(taken, name=name) 

2681 

2682 if self.name != other.name: 

2683 taken.name = None 

2684 

2685 return taken 

2686 

2687 def difference(self, other, sort=None): 

2688 """ 

2689 Return a new Index with elements from the index that are not in 

2690 `other`. 

2691 

2692 This is the set difference of two Index objects. 

2693 

2694 Parameters 

2695 ---------- 

2696 other : Index or array-like 

2697 sort : False or None, default None 

2698 Whether to sort the resulting index. By default, the 

2699 values are attempted to be sorted, but any TypeError from 

2700 incomparable elements is caught by pandas. 

2701 

2702 * None : Attempt to sort the result, but catch any TypeErrors 

2703 from comparing incomparable elements. 

2704 * False : Do not sort the result. 

2705 

2706 .. versionadded:: 0.24.0 

2707 

2708 .. versionchanged:: 0.24.1 

2709 

2710 Changed the default value from ``True`` to ``None`` 

2711 (without change in behaviour). 

2712 

2713 Returns 

2714 ------- 

2715 difference : Index 

2716 

2717 Examples 

2718 -------- 

2719 

2720 >>> idx1 = pd.Index([2, 1, 3, 4]) 

2721 >>> idx2 = pd.Index([3, 4, 5, 6]) 

2722 >>> idx1.difference(idx2) 

2723 Int64Index([1, 2], dtype='int64') 

2724 >>> idx1.difference(idx2, sort=False) 

2725 Int64Index([2, 1], dtype='int64') 

2726 """ 

2727 self._validate_sort_keyword(sort) 

2728 self._assert_can_do_setop(other) 

2729 

2730 if self.equals(other): 

2731 # pass an empty np.ndarray with the appropriate dtype 

2732 return self._shallow_copy(self._data[:0]) 

2733 

2734 other, result_name = self._convert_can_do_setop(other) 

2735 

2736 this = self._get_unique_index() 

2737 

2738 indexer = this.get_indexer(other) 

2739 indexer = indexer.take((indexer != -1).nonzero()[0]) 

2740 

2741 label_diff = np.setdiff1d(np.arange(this.size), indexer, assume_unique=True) 

2742 the_diff = this.values.take(label_diff) 

2743 if sort is None: 

2744 try: 

2745 the_diff = sorting.safe_sort(the_diff) 

2746 except TypeError: 

2747 pass 

2748 

2749 return this._shallow_copy(the_diff, name=result_name, freq=None) 

2750 

2751 def symmetric_difference(self, other, result_name=None, sort=None): 

2752 """ 

2753 Compute the symmetric difference of two Index objects. 

2754 

2755 Parameters 

2756 ---------- 

2757 other : Index or array-like 

2758 result_name : str 

2759 sort : False or None, default None 

2760 Whether to sort the resulting index. By default, the 

2761 values are attempted to be sorted, but any TypeError from 

2762 incomparable elements is caught by pandas. 

2763 

2764 * None : Attempt to sort the result, but catch any TypeErrors 

2765 from comparing incomparable elements. 

2766 * False : Do not sort the result. 

2767 

2768 .. versionadded:: 0.24.0 

2769 

2770 .. versionchanged:: 0.24.1 

2771 

2772 Changed the default value from ``True`` to ``None`` 

2773 (without change in behaviour). 

2774 

2775 Returns 

2776 ------- 

2777 symmetric_difference : Index 

2778 

2779 Notes 

2780 ----- 

2781 ``symmetric_difference`` contains elements that appear in either 

2782 ``idx1`` or ``idx2`` but not both. Equivalent to the Index created by 

2783 ``idx1.difference(idx2) | idx2.difference(idx1)`` with duplicates 

2784 dropped. 

2785 

2786 Examples 

2787 -------- 

2788 >>> idx1 = pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2789 >>> idx2 = pd.Index([2, 3, 4, 5]) 

2790 >>> idx1.symmetric_difference(idx2) 

2791 Int64Index([1, 5], dtype='int64') 

2792 

2793 You can also use the ``^`` operator: 

2794 

2795 >>> idx1 ^ idx2 

2796 Int64Index([1, 5], dtype='int64') 

2797 """ 

2798 self._validate_sort_keyword(sort) 

2799 self._assert_can_do_setop(other) 

2800 other, result_name_update = self._convert_can_do_setop(other) 

2801 if result_name is None: 

2802 result_name = result_name_update 

2803 

2804 this = self._get_unique_index() 

2805 other = other._get_unique_index() 

2806 indexer = this.get_indexer(other) 

2807 

2808 # {this} minus {other} 

2809 common_indexer = indexer.take((indexer != -1).nonzero()[0]) 

2810 left_indexer = np.setdiff1d( 

2811 np.arange(this.size), common_indexer, assume_unique=True 

2812 ) 

2813 left_diff = this.values.take(left_indexer) 

2814 

2815 # {other} minus {this} 

2816 right_indexer = (indexer == -1).nonzero()[0] 

2817 right_diff = other.values.take(right_indexer) 

2818 

2819 the_diff = _concat._concat_compat([left_diff, right_diff]) 

2820 if sort is None: 

2821 try: 

2822 the_diff = sorting.safe_sort(the_diff) 

2823 except TypeError: 

2824 pass 

2825 

2826 attribs = self._get_attributes_dict() 

2827 attribs["name"] = result_name 

2828 if "freq" in attribs: 

2829 attribs["freq"] = None 

2830 return self._shallow_copy_with_infer(the_diff, **attribs) 

2831 

2832 def _assert_can_do_setop(self, other): 

2833 if not is_list_like(other): 

2834 raise TypeError("Input must be Index or array-like") 

2835 return True 

2836 

2837 def _convert_can_do_setop(self, other): 

2838 if not isinstance(other, Index): 

2839 other = Index(other, name=self.name) 

2840 result_name = self.name 

2841 else: 

2842 result_name = get_op_result_name(self, other) 

2843 return other, result_name

2848 _index_shared_docs[ 

2849 "get_loc" 

2850 ] = """ 

2851 Get integer location, slice or boolean mask for requested label. 

2852 

2853 Parameters 

2854 ---------- 

2855 key : label 

2856 method : {None, 'pad'/'ffill', 'backfill'/'bfill', 'nearest'}, optional 

2857 * default: exact matches only. 

2858 * pad / ffill: find the PREVIOUS index value if no exact match. 

2859 * backfill / bfill: use NEXT index value if no exact match 

2860 * nearest: use the NEAREST index value if no exact match. Tied 

2861 distances are broken by preferring the larger index value. 

2862 tolerance : int or float, optional 

2863 Maximum distance from index value for inexact matches. The value of 

2864 the index at the matching location most satisfy the equation 

2865 ``abs(index[loc] - key) <= tolerance``. 

2866 

2867 .. versionadded:: 0.21.0 (list-like tolerance) 

2868 

2869 Returns 

2870 ------- 

2871 loc : int if unique index, slice if monotonic index, else mask 

2872 

2873 Examples 

2874 -------- 

2875 >>> unique_index = pd.Index(list('abc')) 

2876 >>> unique_index.get_loc('b') 

2877 1 

2878 

2879 >>> monotonic_index = pd.Index(list('abbc')) 

2880 >>> monotonic_index.get_loc('b') 

2881 slice(1, 3, None) 

2882 

2883 >>> non_monotonic_index = pd.Index(list('abcb')) 

2884 >>> non_monotonic_index.get_loc('b') 

2885 array([False, True, False, True], dtype=bool) 

2886 """ 

2887 

2888 @Appender(_index_shared_docs["get_loc"]) 

2889 def get_loc(self, key, method=None, tolerance=None): 

2890 if method is None: 

2891 if tolerance is not None: 

2892 raise ValueError( 

2893 "tolerance argument only valid if using pad, " 

2894 "backfill or nearest lookups" 

2895 ) 

2896 try: 

2897 return self._engine.get_loc(key) 

2898 except KeyError: 

2899 return self._engine.get_loc(self._maybe_cast_indexer(key)) 

2900 indexer = self.get_indexer([key], method=method, tolerance=tolerance) 

2901 if indexer.ndim > 1 or indexer.size > 1: 

2902 raise TypeError("get_loc requires scalar valued input") 

2903 loc = indexer.item() 

2904 if loc == -1: 

2905 raise KeyError(key) 

2906 return loc
